FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: We have two Gen Z on our project management team and they are honestly my favorite guys.  They both really get into the work, want to learn how to work smarter so they have less stress (which is how I like to work), and always deliver.  We do have flexible work hours (as long as it's 40 hours a week) and schedule meetings a week in advance at minimum, and there has never been a problem with them showing up to meetings.  However, both of them did need to be coached on "soft skills" and (because this is project management) how to keep things on track when people don't want to meet deadlines.  It's hard for them to be assertive and they don't yet have enough life experience to know how to do it well.  Guess what?  This is something we all had to go through, and the real problem is the lack of mentorship in workplaces now.  You can't just print workers at college and expect them to do everything perfectly for your particular industry and company - you have to develop talent.   I always tell people to ask "how do you develop talent in your employees?" when they interview for a job, and to remember that the interview is as much for you to see if you like the company values as for the company to evaluate you.  Really listen for the answer, and if you get a bunch of marketing speak and buzz words, take that as a sign.  Some jobs are just jobs until you can find your career.  Oh, and by that same token, if you do take a temporary/contract job, always conduct yourself with the same professionalism you would in a full-time job because you never know how that might pay off.  One of the guys I mentioned came to us because he took a temp contract with one of our customers during their implementation, and when we found out they weren't keeping him, we asked if he would consider working with us.   He was professional, chill, and a quick learner who adapted well - all things we look for.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I've applied to over 300 jobs and i can say the very best way to confirm a job opening is through calling or sending a mail to HR. I've called about even older openings and just asks if this is still available and sometimes they even forget that they have it open, when they don't even want to find new people. Tell them your name and what you do and that you would love to send them an application, if they are interested. It's very direct and i know social anxiety is high but this is probably the best way to have direct contact with them make yourself seen and known before you apply. Then when you send an application, they will remember you quicker and look at your application for a few minutes longer than others who just applied without any prior contact. It gives you a bigger chance at getting into the next round of interviews. Hope that helps. Also if you have friends looking for the same thing, make sure to keep in contact and update each other. Gatekeeping Jobs is kind of lame imo

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Millennial here, 7-8 years ago I had the withering experience of applying to hundreds of job postings with only 4 responses and 2 interviews, neither of which I was hired for. I applied to more than 50 jobs with my local municipality and I got zero responses across all of them, just getting flatly rejected months later. So I went to law school, figuring that that was my last chance at being able to earn a living. After graduating, I experienced the exact same thing again, hundreds of applications yielding 3 interviews. The first was for a man I immediately clocked as a total con artist slimeball who thought he could pay 20,000 per year if he guilt trips me enough. The second used me for free work. The third was a 70-year old boomer who still lowballed me and was a 1-hour drive, but I recognised that he was an honourable man, and so I took it. The level of protectiveness he has towards his employees is something I have never witnessed: he will scream at a client that dares to disrespect one of his employees. He may be economically out of touch, but he has my loyalty by being the first boss to ever show me decency.  Law can be highly demoralising work, incredibly demanding, and nowhere near as high-paying as people think it is (especially if you don't want to compromise on ethics, life, health, and relationships), but it was my only shot at survival. The battle you're all fighting reminds me of what I went through, but so much worse. I have utmost respect for Gen Z, you are facing impossible odds in a broken system during its last days before total collapse. Don't ever forget the lessons you learn from this struggle and snipe at Gen Alpha, we all need to work together to transform this hellscape into a better place for those who come after us, even if it's too late for us to see it.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Blame the shareholders and stock market. A company NEEDS to show growth every year, or else the shareholders will demand change. This means cutting production costs, raising item prices, and spending far less on employment opportunities. Deadlines become tighter, and there becomes a shortage of workers, meaning the extra workload is put onto the few that are still employed. This also causes managers to squeeze as much productivity as possible out of those beneath them on the ladder (however they themselves are often pressured.)  So if you get hired, you're going to be overworked and undervalued by the company. Nobody wants to work in a situation like that, and they definitely don't want to do it if they still struggle to feed their family anyway.   And this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't a race to the bottom

As a percussionist i literally have to stay calm while there are hundreds of eyes and cameras watching me or else my hands are gonna jitter and that‚Äôs gonna mess up my playing. Have I ever had a leadership role? Yes I was pit captain for 2 years. What‚Äôs your availability? I‚Äôm completely free now that I‚Äôm out of school. Are you willing to work long hours? I am at school at 7:30am (was 6:30am for jazz band but my siblings didn‚Äôt wanna wake up that early)‚Ä¶and I leave at 9:30pm every Monday, Wednesday, and Thursday because of practice (I don‚Äôt go home for the 2 hour gap between school and rehearsal so I can save gas and practice on my own music for solo and ensemble or school work). There‚Äôs sectionals on Tuesday until 5:30, football games on Friday, and then parade and field show competitions on Saturday where I have to be up at 4am because call time is 5:30am and I live 20 minutes away. I then have to load up the trailer because I‚Äôm a percussionist, get to the place that‚Äôs an hour away, unload the trailer, get dressed in uniform, and proceed to march and stop and march and stop for 2-3 hours in lovely 105F Southern California autumn for 1-3 miles depending on the location (while carrying a drum and playing cadences) just to do a parade at the end and get literally judged because we‚Äôre competitive. Then (after sitting on sunburnt bleachers or just dirt for an hour because of awards) we have to get back to the busses and trailer and either unload all of pit or load up drumline because the field show may or may not be at a different location. Then I have to push everything to a rehearsal spot (GOSH I REALLY HATE THE MIXER WHY IS IT SO HEAVY WITH BROKEN WHEELS). After rehearsing we have to push everything to the school‚Äôs football field and we get like 10 minutes to wait and enjoy the band before us. Then we have to rush everything onto the field and set up, making sure all of the mics and speakers work properly for the pit and soloist, along with the synth and samples, all with a 3 minute timer otherwise we get points deducted. Then we perform our field show infront of thousands of eyes and cameras, some family members, schools that already performed, random people, and judges with cameras. After the performance we have to push everything back to the busses and load up the trailer where we can finally dress out of uniform and watch the last 2-3 bands perform before awards (at 10pm) finally we back on the busses proud of our work and ready to be back at school by 12am‚Ä¶where I then have to unload the trailer and organize all of the percussion stuff neatly in the drum room because I‚Äôm pit captain and have to set an example. Now finally at 1 am I sit in the parking lot and wait another hour all alone to be picked up because my family doesn‚Äôt care despite being night owls. So yes. I can indeed work long ours thank you very much. Oh and during concert season football changes to basketball and instead of driving to the event we host it so I have to help out all of the other schools and be part of stage crew where it‚Äôs setting up stands and chairs for at least 15 schools, most have at least 2 groups or more, and if it‚Äôs chino I have tear down the entire stage so that I can fit all of their own equipment on stage because they wanna use their own timpani, marimba, bass drum, snare, chimes, gong, glock, and literally every other percussion instrument ever because they‚Äôre that big. I also have to keep track of any mallets, cymbals, and toys (stuff like tambourine, woodblock, vibraslap) that other schools might need to borrow. Yes I have to take off any of the big instruments a school won‚Äôt be using like a marimba so that there‚Äôs space for chairs and so it‚Äôs not something just sitting there awkwardly. I also have to tune every note on the timpani by ear several times because some kids will tune it before performing using a tuner which sucks on timps because of overtones and other shizz. And yes, at the end of that day, I have to perform for both the concert band, the wind ensemble, and percussion ensemble, (and any solo songs if I had one prepared at the time). But yes as host we are the last to perform and then we get a little lesson with the judges and then they give our director the ability to pick a random piece from a selection that the judge has and we are given 4 minutes to only look at the piece. No playing or singing. Just look and study. Then we perform and get judged.  Mmm‚Ä¶nah. You don‚Äôt have enough work experience to understand this entry level job. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I'm a high schooler who goes to a school with an EBR (Evidence Based Reasoning) grading system.  For each test there is a scale for 1-4. 1 is developing, practically meaning you either didn't do the work or failed the test. A 2 is called approaching expectations, and it's anything from barely not failing to <90%. A 3 is called Meets Expectations. If you get a majority 3s in a standard or half in an increasing order (like 2-2-3-3) you can get a 3 for that standard. Every class has multiple standards. Some tests only count for one standard while others count for multiple. 4s do exist, and they're called Exceeding Expectations. You'd think it'd be worth it to get a 4, but it's only for your prude. In reality, they count for the exact same as a 3, but are a few times harder to get. Most of the time they require out of class understanding or skills that get taught later in class. For STEM classes, a 4 can only be achieved if you answer a level 4 question, which may not even be on a test. For all of semester 1 this year there has not been a level 4 question in my AP Calculus BC class or my AP Computer Science A class or my Principles of Engineering class.  For an example of how the system works, a calc test has 4 standards. Standards 1 & 2 are about actually solving the problem, standard 3 is about explanations, and standard 4 is about notation errors and the like. If you get a 3 for every standard, then you get an A. A single 2 for any standard is a B. Multiple 2s are a C. A single 1 in any standards is a D or F for the class.   For an English class however, the standards may work differently. In my AP Language and Composition course, there a 3 standards, with each test counting in only 1 standard due to their nature. Standard 1 deals with analyzing passages, and so only Rhetorical Analysis essays are placed there. Standard 2 is about participation, so discussion and reflection grades go here. Standard 3 is about writing, so all the argumentative essays and creative writing are lumped in there.   It's a complicated system unique to each class and is detrimental to the students taking it. It both makes it easy to scrape by if you're barely good enough at each standard and the teacher likes you. However, if the teacher doesn't like you, it's very easy to give you a 2 and block you from achieving an A. My school is very competitive and a B or less is sometimes a cause for teasing in friend groups and lowers your social standing. And don't get me started on parental pressure. Even if your parents stop pressuring you the pressure becomes self enforced.   A lot of other students I know cheat extensively on exams, from learning questions and answers for a math test or learning a prompt for an essay, or simply straight up lying to a teacher for an extension. A lot of people miss tests so they can take them later and have additional prep time. I don't know anyone who genuinely likes their classes and would go to them if they weren't required for college applications. Well, not technically required, but practically.  All of this basically ends up with students cheating, lying, working their butts off to get a grade that says that they simply met expectations. A grade that feels meaningless in a meaningless class. A majority of the people in my AP English class don't plan to go into a career anywhere near Language and Composition.   If you're curious, the school is Adlai E. Stevenson Highschool and the system is only in place because our principal gets money from it and from endorsing it. If your school is considering it, please either switch to another school or convince them not to. A longtime teacher left the school and published a report detailing all the issues with the system and why he left because of it.   TLDR: My school has a BS grading system that doesn't make sense and states that doing your all is simply "meeting expectations".

Anytime I talk to someone my parent's age or older, they often tell me how jealous they am that I'm in grad school because they miss the days of getting to "just be a student" and enjoy learning. I love learning, but no one seems to understand that college students are not "just students" anymore. So, when my generation graduates, gets what they think to be a good job, and start making real money, they are disappointed to find that they still cannot afford to live and that they cannot use this new job to leverage a work life balance. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: It's funny that's even a term used how it is nowadays since the origin of that comment is it was a sarcastic remark made by well of people and company owners to describe an impossible task when the people under them wanted better. It was initially a comment that made fun of those people saying essentially what would be the equivalent of sating something like oh ur working paycheck to paycheck and barely scraping by, well just be a millionaire and that won't happen.
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: The phrase ‚Äúpull yourself up by your bootstraps‚Äù originated shortly before the turn of the 20th century. It‚Äôs attributed to a late-1800s physics schoolbook that contained the example question ‚ÄúWhy can not a man lift himself by pulling up on his bootstraps?‚Äù  So when it became a colloquial phrase referring to socioeconomic advancement shortly thereafter, it was meant to be sarcastic, or to suggest that it was an impossible accomplishment.
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Also because its physically impossible and was originally used as commentary on being told to pretend you live in a meritocracy
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Did you know that ‚Äúpull yourself up from your bootstraps‚Äù was initially being like ‚Äúoh yeah do something impossible‚Äù, like pulling yourself up by your bootstraps! Try it! You can‚Äôt! (Not saying this to like insult ya, I just think it‚Äôs interesting ((„Éªx„Éª))   )

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I'm Gen Z as well, can definitely confirm the whole game has changed. I grew up fairly poor - at least compared to my immediate peers. We were able to finally have our own home when I turned 18, and my parents have both been through college and grad school, having now paid off all their student debt and two nice cars - oh, and they were supporting two children that whole time on less than $100k/yr. Now that it's my turn - I am more degreed than my parents were at my age. I already have an associate's and am one semester away from a bachelor's. Both are honors science degrees - Neuroscience and Biochemistry, as opposed to my parent's degrees which fall under the humanities umbrella. I've been working part-time for nonprofits for the entire duration of my education with wages ranging from $10-$15/hr. I've been volunteering on and off since highschool. My resume is objectively more impressive than theirs was until they were in their mid-20's. And I'm someone who has proven, again and again, I WANT TO WORK.  And, even if I do find a job, am I going to be able to afford even a cheap apartment anywhere up to an hour outside of my hometown? Not likely. There is no such thing as a cheap apartment anymore. The cheapest meals that fit all food groups you can make are at least $10, provided you have enough money to capitalize on grocery deals when they come around. That's $30 or more a day if you're lucky. Grocery prices are out of control.  The "college experience" is a myth for the average student. And so is the American Dream. Millennials were fed lies, so we tried to learn from it. People need to stop blaming Gen Z for shifting their priorities to human connection and enjoying what they can get out of life - because the current state of corporate grind proved we cannot trust anyone to take care of the incoming generation of employees.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I was wondering how things are with the euro. The answer: we‚Äôre obviously being ripped off‚Ä¶ I work for ‚Ç¨1,800 (before taxes) [about ‚Ç¨1500 after] for 40 hours‚Ä¶  Since 2000, the euro has lost about 41% of its value due to inflation, meaning it only buys around 59% of what it did back then. Specifically, ‚Ç¨100 in 2000 would need to be ‚Ç¨168.28 in 2024 to have the same purchasing power. This reflects a cumulative inflation rate of approximately 68.28% in the eurozone, averaging 2.19% annually. In contrast, wage growth has not kept up with this rate, meaning many people feel a financial squeeze similar to what you‚Äôre describing with the dollar in the U.S.  Regarding Austria‚Äôs minimum wage, it‚Äôs currently around ‚Ç¨1,800 gross per month based on a 40-hour work week. Given the euro‚Äôs value decrease since 2000, for this wage to match purchasing power effectively, it would need to be closer to ‚Ç¨3,000 per month to compensate for inflation and reflect an increase in living costs. This difference highlights the growing demand for wages that more accurately reflect inflation and cost-of-living adjustments across many sectors.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: @hatter5834 If by the system you mean the process of corporatization, then I 100% agree. Now it's turned into a signaling contest of which people already in positions of influence and authority you know and how many of them you know - regardless of their demonstrable competencies or qualifications - that you need to schmooze up to so that you too can be boosted to a position of influence and authority regardless of your own demonstrable competencies or qualifications. I think it is hilarious that people point to Gen Z with terms such as, "Quiet quitting", when in reality it  just means Gen Z does not identify their workplace as a foundational structure within their lives like prior generations with more security within their employment did. Back then there was at least some semblance or illusion of meritocracy. Nowadays, we don't even have that.The dramatized TikToks to me are exaggerated versions of this shift in the workforce. The numerous lay offs from jobs that were deemed safe have only fuelled the detachment. I have heard a million regrets of people who were old or on their deathbed, but not once have I heard they wished they had worked harder or more. It is not that Gen Z has wildly different priorities than previous generations, it‚Äôs that socially speaking, Gen Z does not care to uphold the image of ‚ÄúHard worker‚Äù while losing sight of the things that will actually matter in the long run. A company is not going to be at your deathbed, a company will not hold your hand if you get chronically ill, regardless of how many things you sacrificed for it. Work is just work.  And if you are not careful, you‚Äôll retire an empty husk of yourself. Because once your desk is cleaned out and your workspace items of 50 years are packed into an old dusty cardboard box, you may just exit the building you resided your entire life in and won‚Äôt have anywhere else to go.

We really don't want a single payer but need competition in the health system to encourage cost cutting. The hospital systems and insurance companies make all the money colluding with govt.

They often list the ‚Äúnice to haves‚Äù as hard ‚Äúrequirements‚Äù and then offer a salary closer to entry level than senior. As a result, there‚Äôs this skewed system where the hiring manager knows they don‚Äôt have the budget to get the senior and will happily take an experienced person with promise but can‚Äôt find them because HR is being stupid.  Meanwhile HR will argue to offer more. But your budget is your budget; you don‚Äôt set that, senior leadership does. But senior leadership will argue to stop being picky. But you don‚Äôt set the requirements, HR does. You see the problem?  I currently have senior leadership arguing against promoting one of my team who not only  exceeds the HR minimum reqs for their position but the next pay grade too! But their argument is we don‚Äôt have the budget to compensate that person. Meanwhile I have a more senior person underperforming but HR doesn‚Äôt want to demote them because they far exceed the minimum requirements (in tens of skill, experience, and education) üòÇ   Don‚Äôt try to make it make sense; the only way to understand it is that large employers are being pulled in too many different directions and see themselves confused about what they are doing.  I wouldn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúLIE‚Äù on the application; if you straight up lie, I will not hire you; but stretch the truth creatively as far as you possibly can. For example my entry level positions require 2 years of experience‚ÄîENTRY LEVEL, 2 years.. you understand how stupid that is right? We don‚Äôt pay top dollar, we ARE the place you go for entry level experience lol! So the reason why wages have stagnated while inflation has grown, is because the money that should be going into your wages is being funneled into someone else's pockets, and they're spending it.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Deflation isn't good just because it's the opposite of inflation, it's still bad but for different reasons.  What's good for an economy is monetary stability.  As far as minimum wage goes, monetary inflation isn't the issue so much as value of labor.  Yes, costs for goods and services will rise as a side effect, but also when the value of labor is artificially inflated, the demand for the labor will diminish.  In other words, many employers if, say, were suddenly required to double the wages of their workers, will simply lay half of them off and give the remaining workers twice as much work to do in the same timeframe. Companies do this all the time for other reasons, such as a decline in profits, so anyone would be naive to think they wouldn't in this case as well, because it too would effect their bottom line.  I know for a fact that a prior job I had at a company that made layoffs after a bad year didn't replace anyone and just dumped the workload on the people that stayed.

Many founding fathers wanted washington to rule indefinitely, but he stepped down after 2 terms to set precedent that presidents only lead for two terms. After washington leads for 2 terms the first election is between the federalists and democratic republicans, the first parties that formed in 1790s. Unfortunately I believe that political parties are inevitable as people will always have agreements and disagreements in their ideology, and certain people‚Äôs philosophies tend to align in a way that makes some people their political allies and others political opponents.

The number of CS jobs in my market is vanishingly small, which just makes the issue even worse. The whole economy here is based around tourism. So, I'd have to move to have any competitive chance.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: ‚Äã¬†@100percentSNAFU¬†  So basically, "This wasn‚Äôt real capitalism, guys." It‚Äôs the exact same argument: whenever the system produces an outcome you don‚Äôt like, you simply declare its "not real" and try to detach it from its practical consequences  "crony capitalism, it's oligarchy, it's corporatocracy, it's kleptocracy..."  You are just describing the end game of what capitalism is about. In the end capital tends to accummulate in a few hands. These are the predictable results of how capitalism operates in the real world.  We‚Äôve seen it repeatedly: as markets mature, wealth and power tend to concentrate in fewer and fewer hands. Regulations get written by the same people who benefit from them. Competition collapses into monopolies or cartels. And eventually, economic influence becomes political influence, turning the entire system into a mechanism that protects and reinforces the interests of those at the top.  So when you cry about "Thats not real capitalism" what you actually mean is "Thats not the idealized version of capitalism i have in mind". Ideals aren‚Äôt the same as outcomes. In the end, wealth tends to accummulate and power tends to centralize, the end game looks exactly like the things you are trying to dismiss.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Here's the problem: Stocks aren't real money. They're fake money. It's POTENTIAL money.  If you get taxed on a stock, and the stock goes down, do you pay back the taxes that person got taxed for? If no- you're justifying taxing the POTENTIAL EARNINGS of a person. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: ‚Äã¬†@ZeroNumerous¬†your not taxing individual stocks your taxing net worth of all assets using an estimation of their average net worth the previous year. Presumably if their net worth goes down they could defer their taxes with interest to avoid selling at a loss it would increase churn in the stock market but businesses would have more liquidity to buy back those assets when needed. it would be annualized with a monthly payment based on said estimations. Obviously there are more details like do you fully tax primary homes, 401ks, t bills. Probably not but 2% is way more than needed already. The system works fine because the selloffs of stock are consistent, annualized, and expected in downturns people can defer or simply sell better performing stocks holding those that may rebound. The only tricky part is estimating net worths which is the easiest part to game/obfuscate. Here's the thing though if a bank is willing to give  low interest loans on stocks and various assets they are tangible enough to tax. Our currency is fiat anyway stocks are not far off it's all presumed value.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: This is a basic principle of economics. Minimum wage to cost of living ratio often stays the same, regardless of what the minimum wage is. That's partially because company labor costs must be offset by profit, so the higher minimum wage rises, the higher food/retail prices rise in order to meet or hopefully exceed the cost. However, rising cost of goods tends to chase customers away, putting companies in financial crisis and perhaps even closure. This results in more unemployment and less economic activity and competition. So, constantly rising the minimum wage is a terrible and self-defeating policy.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Some thoughts:   Solution 1  - Ban people who own more than 2 homes: easy way to free up the market  - Zoning is needed but on its own it a trap solution: there was a recent study in sf that estimated if upzoning happened it would lower rents by just 100 dollars, and thats instantly getting eaten up by inflation. You need rent caps.   - Social housing is illegal to build in the US. Its gotten a bad reputation becouse it was literally sabotaged and there is a law called the faircloth ammendment that actively makes it illegal for the government to build more housing if it increases the housing supply: this makes it so the only options the goverment has are Things that burn the fuck out of taxpayer money. Either paying out of pockets the diffrences in what tenants can afford (section 8 housing vouchers) or investing in low rent properties that eventually convent to at market housing after a set period of time. Leaving up to the market doesnt work becouse most builders are also landlords and they dont want to increase the housing supply enough to affect their bottom line. You need to split those two up  - BIG one is tentants unions. If youre renting you need to join a tenants union to leverage yourself against landlords. And you need to advocate for laws that strengthen tenants unions.  - Highly recommend reading "Abolish Rent by Tracy Rosenthal" it outlines a lot of policies and means to get substantial protections for tentats   Solution 2  - Also enrcurage more worker copratives: go further than profit sharing, people have a right to have a democratic say over their workplace. When people actually have control over the profits and descionsthey make it leads to more resilient, better paid companies. On the ground workers are better at making descions then distant CEOs and like you said: you need to hold to be able to hold people accountable. We need workplace democracy   Solution 3  - Look Up the blog pluralistic by Cory Doctorow it talks about anti trust though the lense of breaking up big tech. Amazing content  Solution 5  - Some good news on that front: in Montana there is a legal battle attempting to bypass citizens united. Its complicated but basically they are attempting to say as entities, corporations shouldnt have the power to spend money on elections period. Something to watch at least  - We also need more accountability for judges. Much of how the Supreme Court operates needs to be restructured so ancient unaccountable people control so much of our laws  - Big thing is ranked choce voting: we need this in the US to get more than just a two party system  Solution 6  - We 100 percent can do free high quality education. Up until Ronald Reagan was the governor, California had free high quality education and it was actively sabotaged. Billionaires dont like a population thats more educated than they need to be and would much rather you take bootcamps they control vs developing critical thinking.  - People should have the right to learn: both for job training but also to learn "lower value" things people are curious about. Thats how you get a more educated, curious population that isnt susceptible to propaganda.   What you can do  - Highly recommend checking out the working  family's party if you want an org thats trying to do good stuff on a local level.  - Gold standard is to actually help build stuff outside the 2 party system. Even if you got a non corprate canidate, their bosses and peers arent and will activly sabatoge their efforts. 3rd parties arent viable yet, but both parties are ultimately beholden to billionaires so IN ADDITION to voting, we need to look into orgs that arent taking money from big doners. Even if its just on the local level to start  - If you want good resources for unionization, especially on short notice: look up the Emergency workplace Organizing Committee (EWOC) . They provide a ton of support. Even if you dont agree with them politically, your local Democratic Socalists of America (DSA) chapter also had a lot of great resources for helping with unionization, you can exploit them for that.  - Great book to look into for how to affect political change is " The Persuaders by Anand Giridharadas" talks a lot about what you can actually do to change people's minds on stuff. Ussaly its available at your local library or for free on libby  - A great way to learn how to be politically active is to think about the issues you care about the most and see how you can organize to create the most viable small scale alternative today. Care about feeding people? Do a food drive. Care about transit? Start a carpool or bike bus. This isnt going to solve the problem wide scale but it gets you with people who care while doing good and restoring hope in yourself and others and building a poltical movement. If you want a great example of this, look up the history of the black panther party in oakland. Get out into your community, listen to their needs (espeshily those who have been neglected) and you can make things less shit now, you dont need to wait eons on politicans   -Dream big too! We need to not just trail other countries we should surpass them. If billionaires are going to fight the fuck out of you for just a 2 percent tax increase, may as well fight for the 90 percent they had post WWII, the time when the middle class was the most prosperous   -Think bigger than your country. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Alright so first off, yeah. you clocked the problems perfectly. I feel like making a few points though so here goes. -On the use of the term late-stage capitalism (16:00): Capitalism, by its nature, runs off of competition. If a company finds a way to decrease costs, they can decrease prices and outcompete every other company. Because of this, if one company starts treating applicants worse or paying employees less, other companies MUST follow this path in order to compete. Once companies reach the point where they can't actually improve their product or increase efficiency, the only way to grow, a goal demanded by every shareholder, is to treat their (potential) employees worse. Other companies follow, and here we are. So yeah, this isn't greed. any leader who did not make these choices would either be kicked out, or their company would just die. This is what happens in a late stage of capitalism when innovation stops. -On older politicians: It isn't just age. Older politicians like Mcconnell, Trump, Chuck Grassley (R), and Schumer, Biden, Dick Durbin (D), and Angus King (I, caucuses D) have caused more than their fair share of damage to the country and should all be voted out. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Raising the minimum wage would not increase inflation tenfold. It would go up a bit yes, but not that dramatically. The reality is that most people already aren't making anywhere near the federal minimum wage. Most people, even in low-cost of living areas are already making near $15/hr or higher at least. It really should be indexed by the inflation rate, however. The fact that it's been allowed to be stagnant for as long as it has is the problem. If it steadily increased by only a small percentage year over year since 2009, the economy would've had plenty of time to gently adjust to it slowly increasing in the 15+ years since then. However, now, it's so far behind inflation and the cost of living that you kind of just have the rip the band-aid off in the short-term to fix it long-term. Germany, by far the most productive European nation, and the European nation with the largest economy, has experienced almost no economic growth whatsoever since 2008 when accounting for inflation. There's a reason why Europe is waning into economic irrelevance, and why the economies of China and other southeast Asian nations have come to supplant Europe in terms of economic relevance and technological development. It's no coincidence that Europe is absent in the various technological races for supremacy. It isn't the US vs China in discussion after discussion by random chance. It's the US vs China in every single cutting edge topic of discovery and development because those are the two most productive economies with the highest rates of consistent growth that are capable of putting their money where their mouth is.   Europe no longer belongs in the same discussion, unfortunate as that is. By no means would I say I am stunted in life by any action of my own. But I still cannot afford to move out, and I can‚Äôt afford my own car. I don‚Äôt have really any freedom in life and I don‚Äôt know when I will.   I can see why some people would just give up.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I was born in 2000 (I‚Äôm 25) so I‚Äôm right at the edge ‚Äî not fully Gen Z, not quite Millennial. Some people call it ‚ÄúZillennial,‚Äù and that label feels pretty accurate. I‚Äôve always been someone who thinks deeply about the world around me, especially the expectations we‚Äôve inherited about how life is supposed to go.  We were taught to follow a traditional path: go to college, graduate by 22, get married by 25, have kids by 30. That blueprint might have made sense a few decades ago, but for many of us today, it just doesn‚Äôt align with reality. People are living longer, wages haven‚Äôt kept up with the cost of living, and life isn‚Äôt as linear as it once seemed. I absolutely believe in hard work, but I also believe there‚Äôs more to life than just working to survive.  At the same time, I really try to understand where older generations are coming from. Boomers, for example, were raised in a post‚ÄìWorld War II era where the country needed rebuilding ‚Äî and in that context, grinding nonstop and putting your head down made sense. It was about survival and unity.  But now, 70+ years later, the world has changed ‚Äî and so have our values. Millennials and Gen Z care more about emotional well-being, personal growth, and questioning systems that no longer serve everyone. It‚Äôs not that we‚Äôre lazy or entitled (some are). It‚Äôs that we‚Äôre trying to build lives with meaning ‚Äî not just follow a script

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: "Hurt is what traumatizes children", not exactly. Hurt or negative consequences, left unresolved and unhealed, is what traumatizes children.   Adversity is a natural unavoidable part of life. Children who undergo ACE's, or Adverse Childhood Experiences, are usually the most traumatized because their experiences were seriously abnormal with no positive guidance through them, which is what causes the trauma around certain things (relationships, socializing, decision-making, or more specific things like certain sports or types of social events). Hurt, is a subjective experience that requires subjective guidance through how it made a child (or adult) feel both internally and externally. Aside from a physical injury that causes literal hurt or pain, how a child is responded to and helped from that place of hurt is what impacts the child's psyche and if it traumatizes them or empowers them and develops their character and builds resilience and grit.   Risk-avoidant personalities stem from the fear of experiencing something that could be painful either internally or externally, but more so from the fear or lack of ability to know how to move forward if they fail; problem-solving essentially.  But hurt itself is not where trauma comes from. Trauma comes from unresolved problems or negative  experiences.

One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor, and another fig was Ee Gee, the amazing editor, and another fig was Europe and Africa and South America, and another fig was Constantin and Socrates and Attila and a pack of other lovers with queer names and offbeat professions, and another fig was an Olympic lady crew champion, and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn't quite make out. I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn't make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet. "  Sylvia Plath, The Bell Jar   Just a reminder to everyone that people have struggled with this feeling for time in memoriam, and that you have your entire life to achieve the things you want to achieve if you are willing to make the sacrifices it will take to do so. c: of which, there will be an endless amount.  I've coped by accepting and becoming comfortable with "less", and rejecting the idea that we must "have it all". Practicing presence is the most important step for me (which is Sisyphusian for me as a maladaptive daydreamer, but what can you do)  Time is a construct, and so is culture. Cling to the things that make you feel real.

And if you're renting, there goes half your weekly pay. The same goes for cars. I never bothered going for my license as I'd rather get around town on public transport (meaning I can use that time to read or play a game), which means I'm not having to worry about the financial cost of a car, insurance, registration, fuel, parking, etc.

They'll encourage you to find ways to take that insight and make it actionable, so you're not just left with more awareness of your experiences and how they've impacted you.  I always say I hit the therapy jackpot because I adore mine, and she's always pushed for me to actively improve my life as much as I contemplate it.

Now I own a home I'm fixing up, have a retirement and student debt relief from my job, make enough to cook anything I want, survived stage 2 cancer and the only advice I can give anyone my age is: get uncomfortable, live like you're homeless if you aren't already, never engage in capitalism directly and humble yourself through complete humility; which is insane advice when the topic is living in America and not joining a monk village in the mountains.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I've been growing some theories about childhood and how it affects adulthood through my own personal growth as a coddled child.   One theory is that the work we learn to do by watching and being involved with our parents allows for a boost in seratonin when doing it as an adult. For instance, as a child, I went to work with my dad on "daddy daughter day" multiple times where I was in his office, "working" on the computer aside him, filing paperwork, printing, making copies, faxing, etc. all day and now, to this day, I still get a rush doing things like this. The same goes for cooking and cleaning. I was given a job to complete these tasks each week and I still feel good doing the things that I was tasked to do as a child. I realized that we aren't making children "grow up too fast" by having them work alongside us, instead they are just understanding what it means to be a human and get things done (and this isn't a bad thing; reality is good because it is real).    Another theory is that using phrases that praise a child's intelligence or appearance don't do much other than teach the child that everything he or she is saying or doing as well as their appearance is their highest virtue. And this doesn't do much besides lay a foundation of disappointment in the future when they aren't beautiful to someone they want to be beautiful for or they aren't "smart enough" to follow a conversation or gain a position. Learning skills through their own means instead of through praise will take them much further in life because they won't have the stress of comparison weighing on them.  I have more theories, but they're still cooking

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I will say on the topic of therapy, as I work in mental health, the reason it doesn‚Äôt always work or sometimes do more harm than good is because the main type of therapy we talk about and utilize is CBT aka ‚Äútalk therapy‚Äù. As a society, we do not explore therapy like DBT, IFS, EMDR, CPT, and more as much as we could. For me, CBT only worked at a teen and doesn‚Äôt really help as an adult. However, DBT has been very beneficial for me and the way I think through my anxiety in the moment. It also teaches me tools such as direct communication (when it‚Äôs appropriate as well) and mindfulness. There‚Äôs also places like anxiety outpatient programs that can teach one to expose themselves to their fears in a safe way so when it comes up in day to day life, it doesn‚Äôt cause that same level of anxiety if any. I know people who went through outpatients like those and came out being way more resilient and able to face normally anxious situations head on as well as allow themselves to fail.

It's not just the economy like everyone is saying. Every generation has gone through bad economic times before, it's just now we have too much of everything, too much food, too many toys (for kids and adults), too much stuff in general, too many choices in careers, too many people applying to jobs, etc. It's harder than ever to stay away from things we don't like because we are seeing it everywhere. This is however the first generation to have grown up seeing everything before they are old enough to be mature enough when to know when to say no. It used to be childhood was for figuring yourself out and finding your thing, now its happening later and later.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I‚Äôm wrapping up my masters in counseling and need to clarify some of the therapy stuff. The TikTok you showed about trauma is based on the polyvagal theory and it is just wrong. Mainstream neuroscientists accept that the best evidence shows that trauma is stored in the brain, not the body. Bessel van der Kolk and The Body Keeps The Score, while being wildly popular, is presenting a fringe idea in neuroscience that we do not have evidence for. This is why he promotes EMDR which he says isn‚Äôt an exposure therapy. The first problem is that EMDR IS an exposure therapy according to pretty much any serious researcher on the subject, although they will admit it is lighter exposure than the more effective therapies. The American Psychological Association considers EMDR a second line therapy because it is less safe, less effective, not as well researched, and not as suitable for diverse populations as first line trauma therapies. The first line therapies, prolonged exposure and cognitive processing therapy, are exposure therapies. Exposure is important to healing trauma because facing the trauma helps build resiliency, which you said was a good thing throughout your video. These therapies don‚Äôt work when they‚Äôre rushed and the client isn‚Äôt ready, so you have to build a safe space, but not to coddle the client and instead to help them safely face their trauma and gain resiliency. So the goal of these therapies are actually to build resiliency, and when done properly they are considered the safest and most effective therapies. Nobody ever does, but I‚Äôd consider redacting or amending the part about trauma because that idea about trauma not being stored in the brain has dangerously led people to seek less effective treatments or no treatments at all. Look up APA trauma therapies to read more about first and second line treatments, which will back up what I‚Äôm saying about the importance of exposure being necessary when healing from trauma.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I'm a Gen-X'er, I feel really sorry for Gen-Z's, I wouldn't like to be growing up in the world right now and being young like they are.  Most I can say is this, pretty much everything I have learned in life is from not just failure, but complete and utter f*ck-up's.  Does failure suck? Damned right it does, but here is something that was said to me in college that changed my life.  "There is no such thing as failure as long as you learn something from it, you only truly fail if you f*ck up and learn nothing."  So, I go into everything knowing at some point I'm going to screw up, I'll make notes, I'll ask questions, then I'll screw up, sit back and look at why I screwed up, update my notes, then start again, the more I fail the more determined I get to learn more and do more.  As for life itself, as long as you got a roof over your head, food in your stomach, some creature comforts, hopefully decent health, nothing else matters, everything else is just eye candy.  Also, my last tip on deciding on what to do next is this: get 3 pieces of paper and a pen.  Paper 01: Write down everything you think or feel you have to do. Paper 02: Refine that list into what you can actively change or achieve right here right now. Paper 03: list them into order of the fastest to achieve at the top to the most lengthy / difficult one at the bottom.  Then start on paper 03 from task 1, then as you get each one out the way you can strike them off the list, so you are constantly seeing achievements for your time and effort, doesn't seem pointless.  Anything you can't change in the here and now or anything that is out of your control, f*ck it, nothing you can do about it so just deal with it if or when it comes to be.  Pass that onto any Gen-Z'er you may know, it should help them out.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: re the aspect of therapy: i don't fully agree with the part about talking about trauma being bad and keeping it in the past. most people can't effectively keep it in the past if they don't fully process it (which according to the evidence involves talking about it, or creating a trauma narrative). unfortunately, I think the issue is (as someone 1.5 years away from getting their phd in clinical psychology) that SOOO many therapists do not use evidence-based therapies/techniques when people go to therapy. if someone has trauma there are actually ways of treating that (i.e., writing a trauma narrative; exposure therapy) rather than sitting there and "spilling tea." Even for things like depression and anxiety, there are evidence based treatments for that. I work in a hospital yeah and ask people almost everyday if they've been in therapy before. When I hear what other therapists have done with them, I am constantly appalled. Unfortunately, too many therapists think that they can just do whatever they want and it will end up benefiting the patient. that is absolutely not true. And I'm absolutely not naive to think that all evidence based therapy works for every single person without adaptation. I'm a Health equity researcher, so I know that isn't true. ultimately, we need to start with the evidence. you bring up a good point that people And therapy for the rest of their life... I don't think that there's not necessarily anything wrong with this attitude. However I don't think it's necessary either. A lot of this actually probably comes from the lack of evidence based treatment and the lack of connection that we have in our society. People look forward to having that person that gives them their full attention each week or every other week for a whole hour. They can be their authentic self not have any judgment. That connection is healing. It's not necessarily because they have problems that they need to keep working on but there is a level of suffering that is almost unavoidable in such a disconnected society, So for someone who has resources, going to therapy can be one way to mitigate that pressure.
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: 15:25 there's no need to pick yourself up if you haven't fallen yet
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: jesus christ! about the therapy section. the tiktok clip shown (Lauren McGauley) is a COACH, which you can call yourself without even a High School education; she's NOT a therapist with licensure. Trauma being "stored in the subcortical 'subconscious' part of the brain" is not accurate or anatomically possible. Adele Wang: also a "Life Coach" & no academic credentials. Abigail Shrier received two separate Bachelor degrees in Philosophy: also not a scientist. How does this constitute citation/vetting of sources of something so important?  i know psychotherapy (i.e. "talk therapy") is the most well-known one in the pop-sphere, but even a sliver of that has "recalling trauma." EMDR is trendy right now, & has one of the highest instances of being retraumatized.   to give hope: those are a drop in the therapy sphere. Ego State Therapy with a trauma-infromed therapist, TF-ACT (trauma-focused acceptance & commitment therapy), TF-CBT (trauma based cognitive behavioral therapy) & any other trauma-infromed therapist or modality takes all of that into account.  vet your therapist if to find a TF one. that needs to be said w.r.t. "retraumatizing," & beneficial therapies/therapists/modalities. (betterhelp sucks, as does AI therapy.  but i know we all have capitalism to contend with, so sincerest good luck out there, comrades üò™)

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I'm in favor of not having children. (I'm one of those people who never wants to have them), but I feel that in some cases, starting a family was a motivator, or at least a driving force that forced you to wake up every day and give your life direction, even if you weren't entirely sure about anything. Having a child forced you to put up with a job you didn't like, to do adult things you didn't like, and to take on responsibilities you didn't want, but people still put up with it because it was at stake for the well-being of a life you brought into the world. I'm not saying it has to be this way for everyone, there are parents who were always miserable, even with children, and they passed on their own frustrations to those generations. But people who have no direction and went to school, college, and now to work their whole lives without motivation just because it was what their parents and society told them they had to do, in those cases I often see that a child usually gives theem the motivation they need it. On the other hand, starting a family also force you to leave your parent's home and either by choice, because life at home with two families became unsustainable due to clashing ideas, or because their parents kicked them and out of the house, which also hits you with a reality check where you have to survive on what you have, there's no time to look for a dream job, you just take what you can afford and hold on to it to meet your obligations. I'm not saying this is the ideal path, but the truth is none of them are; some things work for some people and not for others.   To get to the end of the road you have to understand that you can't always have what you want (if not most if the time) you just have to make lemonade with the lim√≥n you have, adapt and keep moving.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I don't know if Japan actually does this, or if it's just something I've seen in video games and anime; but "work studies" should really be a thing here. It's the concept of letting middle and high-schoolers actually experience working needed jobs (probably trade jobs) under the supervision of the teacher and the people who work at said jobs. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Late 20s gen-z here who has been in a ton of therapy, so this response will be a little biased.  I think there are a few nuances missing from this take. For the first time in history, women are able to have careers, go to college, and be more independent than our mothers and grandparents. Even my mother, was raised very differently to always put men first and that marriage was the end all be all. We've grown up having many of these injustices highlighted to us from a young age, as they should be. Who decides the marker of "Adulthood" and being successful comes from relationships, drinking, driving, working the same career for 40 years, etc? I'm sure there are boomers who experienced the same thing, delayed license, relationships, etc, in their youth.  I have millennial friends in their 30s who never got a license and I have peers in my masters program who are 23 and have accomplished far more than I could ever imagine at their age.  I don't think it is that we don't want to grow up, but maybe being "grown" looks different for  us now. We are also the first generation to be able to express these complex feelings online, which may just give more attention to things that previous generations left internally. I don't consider a relationship or the age you start drinking as signs of being "grown". I much more value someone's ability to think for themselves, show up as a reliable person when needed, and behave in mature ways. Even if this maturity causes someone to live at home with their parents longer while they save money, go to college, etc.  I also don't fully agree with your point about therapy. I do see what you mean that sometimes in talk therapy we get stuck in this cycle of confirming wounds we have, but i don't think being in therapy for your life is wrong, either. With so much being thrown at us from the internet and the isolation we are seeing in this generation (which i feel again is largely unique), I do not care if someone is in therapy forever and I will not look down on them for that.   I have both ptsd and ocd and will likely be in long term therapy. Even if I were to feel ready to leave, I will be dealing with these symptoms for the rest of my life. I do take breaks and switch therapists, but this idea therapy is leading to us infantilizing ourselves is a bad take, imo. Psychology and Neuroscience are still such new fields that we don't really know anything about. Who knows, maybe in ten years we will find that everything we have done doesn't work or it does?    I also personally do not agree with the term Peter Pan syndrome. This, to me, is a largely outdated term that was used while we did not have the correct terms for other mental issues nor a society that had any leeway for people who's brains work differently. We now accept accommodations, rather than trying to strong-arm someone into acting how everyone is "supposed" to act. I also do not think it is fair to place blame or shame on someone who may be "stunted" for whatever reason.   I do not want to base my success and how far I get in life on the standards of previous generations, especially ones that are rooted deeply in colonialism, white supremacy, and the patriarchy (like being married so young or not living with your family as an adult). I think we have a lot to come to continue to decenter and break down the systems of oppression we grew up on and to unlearn these lessons we were raised on (and our parents and their parents were raised on). Why do I need to be defined by the "American dream"? What if I have no desire to ever live in the white picket fenced house in the little suburban home with my nuclear family? Other cultures often have many family members living in the same home for decades and our elderly were not as abandoned or alone.   While the internet may see us as a group of people who do not want to grow up, I see us as having all the opportunity in the world to figure out who we are. We are getting to take more time and be more patient with ourselves, than other generations were able to (and maybe this is why they are so bigoted and angry). My parents were married with a house and children by my age, but never left the country or really traveled outside of my home state. I have traveled to many continents and if I want to up and fly to Ireland tomorrow I could (granted I do have some responsibilities I would have to arrange first). I think that is really beautiful. My grandmother was a stay at home mom by the age of 19 and I'm not sure what her youth looked like. She has sense passed, but I wish I knew more about what she wanted to be as a child and what her dreams were like.  Maybe instead of being a generation who's worth is based on the way others see us, it is based on how far we grow internally? Maybe the definition of adulthood and its respective milestones needs to be changed?

This is a new economy, and I doubt older generations could survive the expenses we face without going on a riot. We don't need to work harder, we already work hard for nothing. I ended up writing a lot, more than I expected, so sorry in advance! I got the impression from reading that the act of smiling seems slightly difficult, or at least not easy, and it was the same for me in the past but no longer, and I wrote mostly about the progression in hopes that it could be useful or at least interesting to read about.  My mother mentioned to me years ago as a teenager that my neutral face could be very scary, and similarly to what you mentioned, I would have it even when happy. I‚Äôm not exactly sure how I came to my understanding of how facial muscles work, but I changed my neutral expression to be less scary and more‚Ä¶ neutral. Muscles can be extended or contracted, and they lengthen or shorten based on their ‚Äútraining‚Äù. As in, the neutral position of a muscle is not absolute and unchanging. Take the tongue, for example. The optimal tongue posture has the tongue curved and touching the roof of the mouth, but some maladaptive postures have it flat and pushed against the teeth, which causes some facial development issues like stunting jaw development or splitting apart the two front teeth over time (I used to do this). After starting to move my tongue to the correct posture, though, eventually that‚Äôs where it rested neutrally as the muscles adjusted, and my tongue no longer ever tended to lie flat.   I write all this about the tongue because I believe the same applies to the muscles of the face. Partially, though, I was backtracking how I got to this point, as I assume learning from tongue posture back then helped with later changes. My neutral face had the muscles of my mouth almost fully extended, appearing to droop. What I changed was just‚Ä¶ to not let them droop all the way, but actually hold them in the middle between fully smiling and fully drooping. Nowadays I look like I‚Äôm sliiiiiightly smiling. I think of this similarly to abdominal muscles, where the ideal is to slightly tense them and maintain better posture rather than allow your abs to sag completely.   Some muscles that are involved in truly smiling are involuntary, so there will always be some performative aspect to smiling if you‚Äôre not actually happy, but I do believe it‚Äôs possible to not have a scary or sad neutral face through just slightly changing posture and changing the natural resting state of muscles over time. I hope the read was at least somewhat interesting if not useful!

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I think another point that should be considered in this convo is how quickly ableist it can get. Like, there are people out there who genuinely struggle with social interaction. That one girl complaining about how gen-z wants community so bad and then ‚Äúcalls them out‚Äù for also having phone anxiety is what I‚Äôm talking about. Two things can be true. Like, I am not officially diagnosed with anything so I won‚Äôt claim any labels but I know there is something wrong with the my brain. I genuinely struggle talking with people because it feels like an Olympic sport. It‚Äôs like a puzzle I can never solve, and so I‚Äôve developed a lot of anxiety around it to the point where I actively avoid social interaction and end up isolating myself. You hear a lot of neurodivergent people express similar experiences. Some people even develop agoraphobia which is an actual thing. Yes you need to talk to people to build community and that needs to be understood but I also think that it needs to be understood that talking to people is actually really hard for some. Like, god forbid I do the ‚Äúgen-z stare‚Äù while I‚Äôm trying to figure out how to respond to you in a appropriate while also trying to figure out what you even said because I couldn‚Äôt hear you over my constantly overthinking brain and the constant buzzing that‚Äôs always going on outside.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: okay, so as a genz, i feel like a huge part of the whole small talk issue is that in school we were punished for just talking to our friends in class and in between classes wed have teachers yell at us in the hall that its not social hour and we need to get to class, so most of our time being in person was spent not being allowed to just converse with our peers without a reason other than enjoying talking to them, so almost all of our interactions with our peers were through texting and phone calls, and whenever we would go out shopping for groceries or school stuff with our parents, we would be discouraged from making small talk with workers cause the workers would talk directly to our parents, and our parents just wanted to be done with the shopping, and when our parents were hanging out with their friends, we were again discouraged from small talk and hanging out with them because the adults were talking, so we were actively pushed away from in person conversations outside of our nuclear family.  now that we are adults, they want us to do all the things they spent decades teaching us not to do which is just obnoxious honestly.  also with the whole "we dont owe customers friendliness" i can say that for me and most of my friends, we owe it to the customer to be polite, but being friendly tends to get us harrassed by men twice our age who dont realize that we are being friendly because its our job, and not because we have a crush on them.  and that goes especially for waitresses who then also have to deal with even if the man is understanding about it, his partner may get overly defensive and yell at us for flirting with their man, which all in all has just led us to say we are gonna keep the friendliness for our friends, and be polite at work until you show us that you dont deserve our politeness because were not gonna take being verbally abused for 9 hours at a job that doesnt actually pay our bills

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Millenial here. (obligatory "we know") I've seen the "Gen Z stare" done to people, I know I've given the "Gen Z stare". It's... really not new. It's "The Office Stare" given yet another new name. And you're right that it's a couple things that are being grouped together. Generally though it's a face someone is making because they're processing an interaction that's strange or out of the expected to them. That might be someone engaging them in polite conversation in a place they aren't expecting (older gens often don't understand the social cues that younger gens want to be left alone in public i.e. earbuds in on the bus) and their brain is trying to process switching tasks, or that might be a customer/coworker/stranger with incredible audacity and their brain is trying to quickly process how to survive the situation. Our brains are over-worked, over-stressed, under-rested, and under-stimulated. It's not a surprise to see these fast-paced social interactions slow down. Personally I don't think it's a bad thing either to slow it down. I just wish it was on purpose and not because our brains are overworked.
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: idk maybe im crazy but i think this whole "gen z stare" thing is rooted in some type of ableism. like it doesnt matter intentional or not. "they cant socialize!" "why are they looking at me weird!!" like idk man as someone who is autistic and had to grow up mainly around older people ive heard a LOT of things and this just sounds like (mostly unintentional/subconscious) ableism. these people are just mocking how me and a lot of my autistic friends act too :/   and yes, i know this is NOT an autism-only thing. I KNOW. it's just that this is something very common/rooted in autism. i also include general/social anxiety for this comment too, its just autism is a better example i can explain. having this condition (and a few other mental conditions) affects my DAY TO DAY LIFE so of course its... gonna affect how i appear.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I wish more people woild talk about this. I‚Äôm sure its a common experience among people who are neurodivergent.   Lack of social skills are often characterized as ‚Äúweak muscles‚Äù and the solution is to train them by talking to people. but in a neurodivergent brain, something else is happening more akin to neurological disorder or damage.   Someone with parkinsons can train their muscles but theyre still gonna struggle to hold a glass of water. The same way neurodivergent people struggle to respond in ways a normal person would, think of normal topics, and have normal mannerisms.   Neurodivergent people actually do try to learn and train their muscles, and this is how they develop the ability to ‚Äúmask.‚Äù Its like if someone with parkinsons could stop their tremor on command but have to exert continuously to do so.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: ‚Äã¬†@umiiimu¬†just to be clear what my intentions are: covid didnt cause crippling social anxiety, it just brought it to the surface. Which is why i find it funny to blame psych conditions (which normally develop from perpetual childhood trauma) on covid, when it clearly goes deeper than that. In fact, other than covid making these issues starkly apparent to oneself, its totally irrelevant. Chalking it up to covid thus must surely be a jest. Many in this thread have already mentioned its a cultural thing where theyre expected to shut up and anything they say/express can be weaponized against their character. And I get it. But see, so many people from each gen think theyre unique, and while they definitely are cuz its never so simple.. the bigger pattern repeats, just with nuances every iteration. And while life is subjective to each, i think we can objectively agree that regardless of whatever the "gen z stare" indicates about our society, its very existence as a term is evidence that theres a trend entrenched in our society thats consistent enough to be understood by members of the relevant generation without need for context clues... that is to say that the context of common issues (generational nuances) are already lived experience and dont need explaining. And being that history repeats itself, its not difficult to reason the same-different kinda shit has been happening for generations, and unless we get our shit together itll continue. We are already regressing with MAGA, trynna revoke womens autonomy and trample over the spirit of their suffrage. We should make sure we know where we point the blame so we can at least proceed down a path that aligns our intentions with reality. ‚ÄãOtherwise imma just laugh at nonsense like op posted, as if quarantine for 2 years was ever really the progenitor of such widespread societal issues üòÇ   Tl;dr - covid didnt cause your social anxiety

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: @nOwOrnovember¬† this is factual, objectively wrong. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: As a mental health professional, I'm a big believer that there is purpose in contributing to a better culture, and culture itself can have a huge impact on mental health. In my life, I've lived in spaces where you could tell people were only interacting out of politeness, and there was an air of judgement. I've also lived in environments in which people tried to make small moments positive, were more friendly than they had to be, and sometimes even showed genenuine interest. I just feel like doing the bare minimum and being critical creates an air of bad faith to the people around you, and a lot of people with social anxiety would actually be right to feel unwanted in an environment like that. Even if you're an introvert, having a space that achknowledges your existence and offers small signs of support where possible is much warmer. For a generation that seeks connection and genuinely cares about mental health, I feel like large-scale social social patterns could be such a way to improve these priorities. I understand that Gen Z's developmental context and external challenges can explain why they're less outwardly warm and socially savy, but the coldness of some current trends can perpetuate the exact concerns they want to solve. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I once had to explain why gen z americans are so unpatriotic to my gen x dad. I told him that we've never had a reason to be. What we remember is the long-term aftermath: the surveillance state, increased islamophobia, everything in the middle east, etc. The news about Abu Ghraib broke in 2004. We've never seen patriotism used for good, we've only seen it mask nationalism that is used for cruelty and exploitation. Sometimes this makes us cynical and apathetic, but I think it also helps us ignore national borders. Other than ironic feuds with the British and jokes about the Olympics, many of us have very little loyalty to an arbitrary national identity. When we see people suffering, like those in Gaza, we don't care if they're our country's allies or not. I think that can be a very powerful thing.

The most famous one here is probably the Right to Counsel NYC coalition, which successfully made it law that low income tenants have a right to an attorney in eviction proceedings. The organizing and lobbying these local coalitions do can be great catalysts for change.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I was pretty active as a college student in the 2000s during the Iraq Afghanistan stuff.  What I had to learn is that these issues aren't always the Good-Evil dichotomy that would've made it easy.  The problem is that the Good Guys aren't all on the same side.  It's not just that we disagree on what the facts of a situation are.  We also disagree on how we prioritize those facts, and we disagree on what-leads-to-what.  So many people whose views we consider awful can actually be intelligent, well-informed people of good conscience.  The thing we hate, they think will actually solve a problem.  And it's all speculative because, due to the Laws of Unintended Consequences, we disagree on what will lead to what.

If I can be part of the collective healing process that's starting to take hold in our society and help fix the problems that lead to someone experiencing what I did, I think that's actually something worth caring about and something worth fighting for   Letting go of the idea that my life's purpose was in any way supposed to actually be about me and embracing solidarity gave me the perspective to let myself be part of the larger group of people fighting for liberation instead of one person trying to make a difference in a fucked up world. We're social beings and we live in a society that has stripped down the possibilities for social interaction down to almost nothing. Seek out that interaction, seek it out in groups fighting for liberation; learn what it means to truly be part of the proletariat and I guarantee you'll be given a perspective that will necessarily preclude you being able to even begin to give up as easily as you have, right now. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I graduated from GWU in 2011. I was a sophomore when Obama was elected the first time and found myself in the middle of the historic crowd on the national mall when he was inaugurated. National guard were at every street corner, rifles in hand. Snipers on all the rooftops around the mall. And in the middle was a massive crowd of people, happy, cheering. I still remember when Obama came out and was made president, all the cheers, the immense emotional release from so many. Wails and tears streaming down the faces of the black women near me. I could see and feel the pain, generations of it pooring out, as if the image of this black man standing there on stage finally gave them permission to breathe and to hope. It was heart wrenching. I wanted to hug them, to take them away from there, this spectacle. I wanted yo tell them "He is not here for you. He is the same as the other white man he's replacing. He's using you. You don't need him, you are strong and you are perfect. Trust yourself, trust those you love, and know all these liars on stage are at war with you." But the momentum was too much. So i just watched, knowing where it would lead, blindly but surely ebbing away at people's resources, making life even more unnecessarily difficult. I remember knowing all this before i left my dorm room to go to the inauguration,but i made myself see it. I wanted an image to remind me of what happens when hope is blind. Now, 16 years and 4 elections later, I'm not hopeful, but I'm also not hopeless. Im steadfast. Steadfast in the fundamentals. Food, home, teamwork. It might seem overly simplistic. It may not seem to be a solution to monumental tyranny. But it is revolutionary. If your time, money, energy is spent, it does not come back to you. It goes out into the system where is is consumed for war. The more you conserve yourself, your peace and wellbeing by valuing the fundamentals, the more you create an economy of peace and wellbeing around yourself. Every noment, every dollar you give to that, is a moment and a dollar not given to the war machine. The War Machine. Sounds big. Sounds insurmountable. It's not. How so? It's not just a war on others. It's at war with itself. It is at war with its own foundation, the fundamentals. The better it is at destroying, the more its gears and wheels rust and crack. It is only a matter of time. Withholding your energy, remaining calm and healthy, only quickens its demise. Stay informed, stay aware. Conserve your time, money, and energy. Embody this. Sharing this is a natural byproduct, then opportunities for teamwork naturally arise with the likeminded. This is how yhe revolution grows inside the belly of the machine, with steadfast in knowledge and self love.
