FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I found it interesting that the platform identified as having given gen z unprecedented insight into the horrors on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean is TikTok (around the 54-55 minute mark), kinda wrapping up the section on the distrust of mainstream media. Why I find it particularly interesting is that as far as I can tell, the USA's continued support for Israel has approximately nothing to do with what's going on in the Middle East (it used to be about Middle Eastern oil, but oil is kinda over) and everything to do with TSMC and China.  To fill you in on the TSMC/China connection, think for a second about the CPU and GPU in your phone and laptop, and maybe your watch if that's your thing. Those, and pretty much every advanced chip in any device you own (or that the military owns) was made by TSMC. I mean sure the branding says its made by Intel or ARM or Nvidia or... But just like an iPhone is only designed by Apple, and is actually made by Foxconn, those chips are only designed by the companies whose name is on them, and are actually made by the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (which is what TSMC stands for).  Now you may also have seen in the news that the CCP believes Taiwan to be a part of China and would like to reassert political control over it, and one of the main reasons that it hasn't just invaded is because it's worried about the USA getting involved. Now the TSMC foundry in Taiwan falling under CCP control is unlikely to stop the chips from being exported in laptops and cellphones, but they might want to slap some export controls on equally advanced chips that might be destined for, say, a targetting system on a tank or a fighter jet, or a guidance system for a missile.  Basically, the US government doesn't want to be on the ass end of the same sort of sanctions that were slapped on Russia after they invaded Ukraine. The current means to achieving that goal is to maintain an alliance with the government of Taiwan, where the USA continues to get the advanced semiconductors that it needs to equip its military, and the Taiwanese government gets assurances that the USA will back them militarily if someone (probably China) tries to invade.   The problem on the eastern shore of the Med is that the USA needs its assurances around the defense of Taiwan to be credible for that whole alliance to work. If the US were to withhold support from Israel (for the obvious reasons) then it would lose Taiwan's trust. This might invite an invasion of Taiwan, or it might motivate a political shift away from the USA and towards China (allowing China to achieve the goals of invasion through soft power instead). Needless to say, the USA losing Taiwan's trust is a win for the CCP.  Now TikTok is effectively controlled by the CCP, who has a clear interest in undermining American support for Israel, because it makes Taiwan easier to take over. Coincidentally, gen z's protests against Israel are described in this video as being motivated by videos exhibiting the horrors visited on the Palestinian people --- as viewed on TikTok.  I'm not going to say that gen z is being played; every indication I have is that to the extent the CCP is putting these videos on the phones of young Americans, that activity is an information operation rather than a disinformation operation (the content of the videos generally tracks with the descriptions of conditions provided by relief agencies and other NGOs). Rather what I want to point out is that the new TSMC foundry that's getting built in Arizona is basically a giant middle finger from Biden to Netanyahu, because the next time (after that foundry opens) some Israeli leader gets it in his head to do the sort of thing that's being done now, it's going to cost the US a lot less geopolitically to tell Israel that they're basically on their own. It may not feel like it, and the injustice of the pace at which these things happen can be frustrating, but gen z should be told that they are making progress on this front, that they are actually wielding their power as effectively as any of us in preceding generations ever did, and that they will eventually accomplish their goals.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I'll criticize one of your points; as someone who is Gen-Z and a Communist, I am very adamant that there is no logical reason to vote for Democrats.  The reason being is that political power is premised on class control of the state. Both Democrats and Republicans represent the interests of finance and big business, using different legislative means to organize that power. Neither party would disposes the fraudsters and criminals who got away with crashing the economy in 2008. Neither party would take the steps China does where they imprison or execute CEOs for corruption.  Voting for either party is as meaningful as not voting. Everything is premised on the interests of people with money you can't ever imagine having. They make the decisions, not you.  Your vote is meaningless because there is no organ of working class power. If you want to have political power and efficacy -- at least, from the perspective of myself being a Communist -- the only way to do so is to join or start a Communist Party and mobilize other politically conscious people to start earning the trust of the masses, gaining political power, and building up institutions and networks independent of the state. Or in other words, follow the successful examples from the Bolsheviks, Chinese revolutionaries, Cuban revolutionaries, and so on and so forth.  I will not vote, ever, for any party that upholds mass murder, that protects the interests of finance capital, and that abuses its citizenry with platitudes about civil liberties and human rights. Nothing matters until you actually have a political voice, and you only get a political voice with a state run and controlled by the working class.  Harris being elected would simply mean your rights and liberties to not be discriminated against due to sex, race, gender, sexuality, etc. would be hung over your head by a party of people who do nothing, who gaslight you into voting for them by saying the other party that actually does things will do things and be bad.  The simple fact of the matter is that both so-called "parties" are just two wings of the same party. The United States is run by a single party -- a political party that represents the interests of finance capital -- with a more socially liberal wing that wants to use state intervention more often, and a more socially conservative wing that wants to reduce state intervention. Both of them are fine if a law was passed tomorrow that rounded up and imprisoned all LGBT+ people so long as profits didn't go down.  All Democrat and all Republican politicians hate you and every other American citizen by virtue of what they do and what they represent. That will only change when the entire political apparatus of the United States is smashed and replaced wholesale by a working class government.  As such, there is no reason to vote, ever, because voting will not protect you, only the masses organized at your side will you find protection and liberation. The house slaves were not better off than the slaves in the field, and the house slaves would only be liberated in joining the field slaves in a slave revolt, or fighting against their masters. The American citizenry today take on that legacy from the slave plantations, but in a modernized form.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: So you joke about the eminem thing at the end, but that kind of activity online is indicative of what I've been calling the Dissatisfaction Quotient, or the tendency to engage in apparently pointless disruptive behavior as a response to extreme stress. I know the example is a bit goofy but hear me out.  When a creature experiences pain or suffering, their attempt to cope may manifest as seemingly useless destructive tendencies, like lashing out with no clear goal or apparent gain. This can range from self mutilation to interpersonal violence to destruction of property, et cetera. No feeling creature is always rational. We can act out of intense emotion when under great duress, and when we act out of desperation, fear, or rage, sometimes we do things that hurt ourselves, or damage our environment, or sabotage our opportunities. When stress or pain are at their peak, we become deeply irrational and interact with the world in a way we would find embarrassing if circumstances were better and we had higher standards for our situation.  The current state of the world both domestic and abroad offers no shortage of stress, and the online ecosystem is hostile to consumers and their mental health in a tangible way, exacerbating an already unprecedented level of brain rotting. Pair "the instinctual response to stress is to lash out" with "machine designed to stress you out," and you get presumably once-normal people very comfortable with regularly doing things that are broadly inconsistent to how they conduct themselves in their normal lives.   People who haven't paid attention to eminem in 20 years suddenly developing very strong opinions is an exercise in wielding emotional authority in a way that feels productive because nothing else in life feels productive or like progress so this is a meager but acceptable substitute for purpose.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: the original idea of these generations is to simplify things to try to observe some trends. and yes, it is imperfect from the get go. no matter where you draw the lines, there will be people like your sister who are close to the drawn lines and have life experiences from two generations.  there are of course some generational differences, in broad strokes.   the Greatest Generation (they named themselves that, I think?) are the generation that were young adults during world war two. many of those men served in a brutal war.  the silent generation were children during world war 2 and while they witnessed parts of it, they didn't personally serve in that war  the baby boomers grew up in the cold war. they also grew up in a period of economic growth and opportunity  Generation X lived through the counter culture movements of the 70ies and 80ies, they witnessed the end of the cold war in their youth or early adulthood.  Millenials were born after the cold war, they witnessed mobile phones becoming more comon, the internet getting established and so on.  gen Z was born when internet was already basically completely spread out in the western world. they grew up with social media being dominant.   gen alpha is still very young and not quite as defined yet but a large part of the life they can remember was dominated by the evil cough that youtube doesn't like mentioned    obviously those life experiences will have SOME effect on the worldview of these people. someone who lived through world war 2 has very different experiences than someone who was born in the early 90ies. so, in broad strokes, the generations make sense. of course they do not actually apply for individuals, just for the larger group.  for instance, my wife and I were both born in 1990. I was born in switzerland, she was born in bulgaria. I lived through incredibly peaceful and prosperous times for my country, witnessed internet as early as it spread, got a mobile phone early and so on. she lived in a country that was struggling to rebuild after the collapse of the warsaw pact. she lived in harsh poverty. when we met in 2014 she only had internet at home and a mobile phone like I had about 10 years before. she bought her first smart phone in 2015. obviously while we are very clearly in the same generation, our life experiences are still quite diferent. just to give an example.  PS: I am a bit confused by the american gen Z. because , the gen Z i got to know in switzerland and italy when I worked as a teacher was quite different. they were quite optimistic and politically engaged.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Societies form to allow specialization such that provisioning can be done more efficiently and in greater volumes for all of its members. Healthy and holistic citizens advocate nurturing policies and will not begrudge resource usage with best practices procedures to see the nurturing done. The assumptions are based on the idea that whatever provisions are produced will be applied to the meeting of basic needs equitably. They are also based on the idea that everyone will have more time to focus on quality of life enhancements, equitably. But, most of all, although often unspoken, it is founded on the idea that the members who do not proclaim themselves political sociopaths with their actions deserve optimal autonomy and not just to simply survive.   Individuals have as much a "right" to choose a healthy and holistic collective set of principles to follow as they have a right to manifest autonomy outside a healthy society. Yet, these choices are a matter of power. So, where do these boundaries of choice reside and when do we apply the principles decreed by a collective? Well, that is the learning curve for each and all of us. This is a process we can collectively utilize determination that will be done both individually and collectively. This is rather self evident yet not very well positioned in the societal creation modelling.  Hierarchy is a privilege creating structure that is sociopathic in its inception. Economic hierarchy being the most destructive to the society. It interjects competition into contexts where only provisioning is required. It detracts from the goals of healthy society creation with competitive conflicts of interest such as click formation, withholding knowledge and resources from the provisioning processes, and with the general distractions of conflict. Capitalism is the mechanism by which political sociopaths establish the hierarchies of dominance. This is why we should never afford political sociopaths adult authority in a society that seeks to be healthy and holistic.  Profit seeking and competition are not necessary in provisioning at the currency issuer level (federal congressional). All federal spending is newly created currency and stimulates some part of the private sector economy. There are plenty of scientists and support staff qualified workers who would love to be employed by the government or a worker owned cooperative with a federal contract to research and make pharma products without the investment capital sociopaths injecting their world domination agenda into our healthcare system and provisioning of other necessities.  Unhealthy societies are what happens, over time, when political sociopaths are afforded adult authority in a society. Political sociopaths work to normalize the sociopathy. A political sociopath is someone who is willing to do harm to another for the sake of opportunity, social capital, hierarchy, profit and/or pleasure. Its a class of behavioral choices, not a diagnosis. A reduction in our tolerances for politically sociopathic choices and those who reserve a right to those choices in any and all governance, adjudication, implementation and enforcement of policy will lead us to a healthier society.  After seventy thousand years of attempting to create civil societies rather than just opportunity centers we should not be surprised that this would happen. But, humans are reticent to give up choices or take responsibility even when dictated by their own moral ideals.  Dichotomies of political choice are made sociopathic with balkanization and empowered through consensus.  This principle assists in policy creation and framing when applied to these dichotomies.:   demographic defense nationalism religious ideology justification meritocracy as an ideology meritocracy as a tool for mission expediting hierarchy as an ideology hierarchy as a competitive advantage consensus as an ideology  All governance will descend into oligarchy, plutocracy and fascism at rates that are determined by the quality and stability of its consensus seeking strategies, the tolerance/intolerance of bad faith actors in its processes, its best practices policies and the quality of the documentation of data that goes into the making of its policy choices.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Hello, I just want to post here regarding the energy side of Gen Z politics. And by that, I mean literal energy, the stuff that powers your lights and computer and phone and heating and AC and dish washer and car. The vast majority of emissions that has caused and will exacerbate climate change are done for the purpose of energy production, an industry that will only continue to grow and also be continuously damaged due to said climate change (look at Texas during 2021 Winter Storm ).  For energy politics it begins with information. Local, state, and federal governments are all to happy for you to NOT know where your power comes from, or to vaguely gesture at the industry in only positive light. Look into the types of energy production methods by source of energy, AKA methane gas, coal, biomass, wind etc. Understand the politics behind them as well. You'd be surprised to know that there is an entire PR movement dedicated towards keeping the words "natural gas" and "methane" as far apart as possible. Or to learn that large portions of the "renewable" biomass industry just involves having private industries tear down old growth forests in the US, pressing them into pellet fuel, and then exporting them to other countries to be burned and generate CO2, with the "renewable" part being the promise to plant new growth forests that will not pay off the carbon debt from the initial clearing and burning.  Gen Z is also more in favor of nuclear energy (as is the US in general), but current nuclear projects are not exactly what we need at the moment. Far too many of them are being headed by big money investors like Bill Gates or Peter Thiel in hopes of creating Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) that are meant to power specific projects like data centers and not, you know, municipalities. While these projects are good for research and are at the very least not spewing CO2 in the air, nuclear reactors need to be replacing coal and methane plants that already exist. Also, there is a weird sort of "pro nuclear but anti renewable" thing going on with right wingers and centrists but the ideal is to use both in a mixed grid.  My biggest issue with the left on energy politics is the refusal to provide a hopeful vision of the future, which is what people like. Unfortunately, you need older people to agree with you on this and they tend to dislike it when you say, "we need to do mega-degrowth now, you will lose your standard of living and like it grandpa it's for your own good."  Regardless, good video, I can tell it was difficult to make due to IRL events and a lot has happened these past 10 months!

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: As someone with blatant ADHD, I found that when I do a project, the best motivation to actually finish it, is to just start it immediately (before I've even finished planning it, when I'm most excited to actually do it and before I lose interest) and leave it in the middle of my workspace. I don't even have all the parts yet, but this incomplete mess inconveniences me, and it will continue to get in my way daily until it's fully assembled and completed. If I pack it up into some box and throw it into the basement and say "eh I'll get back to it later, I need the space for something else," that day will never happen.  In short, "lock in" on your current project until it's done. Don't put it away and start a new one in the middle because you'll "get back to it," and don't hesitate to get started on it just because you haven't planned everything out to perfection and analyzed every possible snag. By the time you complete a plan that thorough you'll have lost interest, so just start now and plan as you go! (This is a common problem with perfectionist types)

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: It's my 2 year anniversary of being locked in, I think I got 3 more to go but honestly might just stay here. Word of advice to anyone that may be reading, don't try to give up distractions, just take control of what distracts yo u and allow yourself to be distracted occasionally. The grind feels badass, but if you never stop to allow yourself to be swept up by life, you'll reach the other of the two extremes and feel like you're not quite living. I'm not sure how to explain this, but it's so important, so I'll try; there's a certain ability which is very hard to gain conscious control over, it feels like uncoiling the spring on the minds clockwork, a very deliberate investment in allowing all your senses to feel. Honestly, it's also a type of focus; there comes a point where the focus on the grind becomes so distracting that all your channels of orientation within reality become dampened. When the quality of your reality suffers, you subconsciously lose some of your motivation to remain at your task within it. Enough focus to realize that you're human, with human limitations, and wind back the pendulum swing trying to view the opposite extreme as the easy fix. Changing one's mindset isn't enough, we have to be able to cultivate our reactions, perceptions, ideals; in order to find balance. Shifting just enough to not fall over. If you never focus to deliberately chill out, you'll never be able to really lock in.   Running at 50%, 85% of the time. Took a long time to get to that point. Even running at 40%, 60% of the time seems to be better than what most are doing; certainly better than running at 110%, 1% of the time (we all started there, it's miserable). You WILL need to be delusional if you're set on turning a want into a need; and that comes with its own downsides, the main one being that actual needs become neglected once you're willing to literally throw your life away in pursuit of a dream. Hold on the just enough realism to realize that dreams cannot be pursued by a dead man. In hindsight, it's crazy feeling like you're starving because you took some time to eat and stay healthy; but it's also one of the best feelings, because that's what purpose feels like. Don't let purpose kill you, don't let yourself die without it. Cheers.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I, respectfully, disagree. Maybe I'm built different (and by different I mean "stupid"), but I used to workout because I hated myself. When I stopped hating myself I found myself still going to the gym. Why? I don't know. Habit, I guess? And there it is, your motivation, our "why" must be just strong enough for you to do the thing you want to do for like, a month. Maybe two. Then gym becomes brushing teeth. It just happens. So ok, I still had a strong "why", but then COVID happened. My habit was gone, I gained weight and going back to gym was demotivating. So what did I do? I made my goals really small. "Go to the gym", that's all I wanted myself to do. If you want to quit 5min after you arrived, do it. If you want to check in, go to the changing room, look around and just leave - do it. But your goal should be small enough, you'd feel ashamed if you failed. And then you build on it. Ok, I went to the gym, sometimes I went home early, but now we're 3 months in, going to the gym takes no mental effort whatsoever. Let's start expanding that goal. Few people who start with the goal of "I want abs" get abs. But people who start small might just get them one day. I have no real why. I guess my "why" is because I am in control. There is that section of my brain that is responsible for being me. And there are other sections of my brain that are responsible for other stuff. And I won't my brain stand in my way. I 100% agree with 28:15 tho. If you go on a diet, go ahead! look for low calorie, but filling  food. But expect that there will be hunger and cravings. If you are like "I ate stuff because I was hungry", well what did you expect? anticipate difficulty and have a plan.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I liked the video, but I wish it had tackled decision paralysis. It plays a huge role in why ‚Äúlocking in‚Äù rarely works out. Sure, it‚Äôs great that we have the internet and can access basically any information we want but it‚Äôs also the very thing that fuels our addiction to finding the most ‚Äúoptimized‚Äù way of doing things. It creates this paradox where the more tools we have, the harder it becomes to commit, because they generate the feeling that every choice might be wrong or inefficient. That‚Äôs why there are so many extreme routines floating around online. People often don‚Äôt realize that ‚Äúoptimized‚Äù should mean optimized for them, not just copying some influencer‚Äôs routine. The mindset of ‚Äúthey have what I strive for, so it must work for me‚Äù is incredibly common and it‚Äôs another reason why locking in fails. In theory, decision paralysis is a relatively harmless defense mechanism. It is an attempt to avoid failure or making the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù choice. But if you‚Äôre trying to reach a goal and genuinely don‚Äôt know what to do (which is why I find the statement ‚Äúyou know what to do‚Äù a bit troubling), you‚Äôll naturally start researching. And that leads to a massive pile of contradictory information, no matter the topic. AI doesn‚Äôt help much here either. It tends to give ‚Äúone size fits all‚Äù answers, and even if you don‚Äôt like the response, it‚Äôll just adapt it to your preferences without necessarily checking if it‚Äôs actually good. Its priority is your satisfaction, not your success (plus it can make things up out of nowhere yada yada). So people get stuck in this endless loop of analysis paralysis, constantly searching for the ‚Äúbest‚Äù solution and refusing to try anything until they‚Äôve found the perfect routine. It‚Äôs not always about short-term pleasure. It can also be about the obsession with finally making it work this time, as we grow more desperate with each attempt.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: If someone read 20 pages of atomic habits they would probably understand this concept pretty well. The author goes into his backstory on how his life was transformed not by one defining moment but by adding little improvements to how he lives everyday and continuing that for years. The concept of "locking in" is usually seen as a drastic change to ones routine but that usually not possible to implement long term. You need to start slow, for example if you want to lose weight start by going for a 15 minute walk every day or cut out 200 calories, stick to that habit and over time incrementally do more in your life.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: This is the best, most real video ive watched on youtube. Me personally, as a 15 year old kid, trying to make it in life like any other person also have that random burst of motivation that fades away quickly. But a thing that I've noticed between every single famous person or between the people that achieved their goals in life is discipline. Everyone knows it, but very few people actually commit to their projects because they dont have a reason to do so. This video explains that perfectly. And as a guy that has also tried all the things like having my own print on demand clothing store, dropshipping and reselling I've learned a lot of lessons, because I wasnt the person that just talked about doing it, I actually did it. But also, I wasnt the person that succeeded, I learned, spent hundreds of euros down the drain, got made fun off, while the others were spending their money on drugs and alcohol. But these projects taught me a lot of lessons. First of all, if it seems too good to be true, it is. Success comes with a LOT of effort and you dont see 99% of the effort another person put in to become so great. And secondly discipline is needed to achieve great goals, but dont forget your brain. Focusing on a goal and trying to pursue it is great, but dont forget critical thinking. If something is too saturated or if you see someone talking about it on the internet, its already too late and you need to know when to stop and changs niches. As i said, everything can be achievable with enough effort, if you focus on one thing for 10 thousand hours, chances are you are going to see results, but instead if you spend 100 hours searching for the right thing to focus on and another 5000 hours grinding on it you will achieve your goals quicker. Dont get me wrong, i think perfectionism isn't good but you can find good in anything at a certain dose or level. Mamba out

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: The reason most don‚Äôt lock in is because it‚Äôs lonely. Most of your friends aren‚Äôt locked in so you will lose most of your friends. You won‚Äôt go to their birthdays or out on the weekends because your competition isn‚Äôt doing that. They will stop calling and texting you. Your world will get lonelier.   If your family aren‚Äôt world experts at what you care about, your family will also be alienated from you. You won‚Äôt eat the same meals or be awake at the same times as them, you will develop a different vocabulary and world view from them. You might move away. Your head will fill with different thoughts and your internal dialogue will depart from theirs until you become unrelatable.  As you deviate into the upper percentiles of the population at your given task, even strangers will see you as weird. You will have trouble communicating with normal people because you have little in common and spend limited time socialising. People will see you as an outsider because you are so far at the tail end of the distribution that they can‚Äôt relate to you. This goes for relationships where people you would otherwise court are impressed by what you do but don‚Äôt understand/ can‚Äôt tolerate to invest in that thing like you. Very few relationships are good for a locked in candidate so you will avoid most potential romantic partners.  Some avoid the issue by seeking out other locked in people and moving as one. Being part of the elite group might raise your game and you may be regain the feeling of social inclusion.   Two problems:  1. Elite groups are hyper competitive and you may need years of locked in isolation before being accepted. Most will not tolerate frequent social isolation for years.  2. You may not feel social inclusion among the elites. Elites can be pretentious, big headed, or cliquey. You might find them so intense that their behaviours are unhealthy, even if your association with them is improving your craft.  The last problem doesn‚Äôt apply to many people, but if you want to be the BEST, not just locked in, then you actually need to outperform the elites. In this instance they start seeming to you like your family and friends once did. As you look for competitive edges you relate to them less. Eventually, even the elites treat you with deference and caution, like  professional soccer players viewing Messi.     Now, hanging out with elites might actually hold you back from being the number 1. And there may exist another version of you who will make that sacrifice to beat you (e.g. Ronaldo). So you start earlier and stay later and do extra when others aren‚Äôt watching (like Kobe‚Äôs famous 5am workouts). There may exist no one like you at this point. You are unique and that‚Äôs a very lonely feeling.    That‚Äôs one reason why it‚Äôs hard to lock in

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Motivational bursts that we all are very familiar with, but this disease makes an illusion of our helplessness in the long term. Have you heard about all the distractions in the vid? This is exactly what you have to target for the most easy way to success. Your brain usually isn't able to handle so huge reasoning, cuz our needs and wants are running on the subconscious level and your consciousness is always intermediary, there is no way to change that. So to minimize the effects of subconsciousness  you have to maximize your consciousness' efficiency. It's much easier to follow some pre-accepted rules than processing them over and over again. More simply, planning is the best way of getting succeed. Plan what exactly you have to do and don't have to do. You can either use time frames or not, it doesn't matter that much. We all have goals inside our minds that we believe/hope we will one day reach. We like to think that when we reach this goal, we will finally be happy and content in life, and maybe it will ‚Äúmake us whole.‚Äù This is, for the most part, a complete lie. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: first step: understand your conditioning. everything in your life that lead up to who you are right now. breaking that programming is like trying to be a different person with different conditioning. if you literally woke up tomorrow as a different person, you'd likely go into psychic shock/hysteria when you looked in the mirror. changing your subconscious programming is incredibly difficult. even if your conditioning is hurting you. the other problem you need to overcome: people always perform better when they are having fun. what you find fun has  a LOT to do with your conditioning. you weren't born a gamer or a football player. you BECAME that (or something else). you may "wish you were" a this or that. but if you don't enjoy doing what "this or that" does, you will never truly become it. at best, you'll become a miserable faker and look back on your life with regret. the other big issue you'll face is understanding your conflicting desires. example: you want to have kids but you don't want to commit to a relationship because you're afraid someone better might show up and you'll regret your decision. how you (whoever you are) deal with these issues is up to you. but being aware is the start.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: I think the video had a lot of good advice, but I also disagree with the magical why notion. When I do something challenging for a long time, I don't often have a grand "why." For me, I start because I just want to do it. And then, I keep at it because my "whys" evolve with the goal. Like, let's take learning an instrument, for example. Why? Because I wanna. I like music. I start. I learn a couple very basic ass songs. Then I want to try more complex stuff. And my whys keep changing. First it's "I want to learn this harder song because I feel accomplished when I pull it off" and later "I want to learn the lower register so I don't get tripped up by random low notes" and then "I want to play faster so I can play that awesome video game song" and later "I want to learn notes by ear so I don't have to use sheet music to play anything"  There's no grand goal. Nothing like "I want to be a famous musician" or "I want to surpass so and so" or "I want to impress someone with a specific song." The goals, my whys, just shift as my skill improves. The first why is just because I wanna. That's it. I think whys that evolve with your progress are more realistic than starting with a magic why bullet and expecting just that to carry you to the end. Granted, he kind of touched on that with the Y squared thing, but I don't think it was emphasised enough.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Yes, the easiness of modernity is a killer of greatness, but is the extreme opposite "reality check" of what it takes to reach our goals also a killer? The focus on the end becomes so "locked in" that we forget that the journey itself is where depth and meaning exists if we remember to stop and look. Like the Grand Canyon example. The snapshot you have of it now, as a mental visual image, isn't the end of its journey. Every day, rain still falls there, mice push rocks around, life exists, unfolds, dies, and decays there, changing it slowly but surely. All that is what MAKES the Grand Canyon, not MADE it. It's an ongoing process, sometimes quickly, other times slowly, but still evolving. It seems to me that a very important aspect has been lost in looking at the extremes.  Most people don't know their why because they don't even know their goal, and this is where I then have a problem with the "extreme reality check". Being told that only goals worth walking through hell to achieve are worth our attention is as much a killer of finding depth and meaning as doom scrolling is. If we're so focused on finding a "worthy" goal and a why that can survive the how, will that alone limit our snapshot of "the end" possibilities to become the next problem in finding a goal: Only to look among those that will surely cost us the most discomfort. Where is the room for life, for depth, for meaning, for the love of the journey. Why do we treat our lives as if they're modeled from the new modes of productivity that arose with the industrial age, where everything can and must be tracked, measured, weighed, and optimized? That's the killer of the human experience. That's why we doom scroll. Because we forgot something that has no room in the world as it looks today.  Buddha once held a sermon where he remained quiet but only held up a flower. Those present stared at it in deep contemplation to figure out, what lesson there was to be learned. And then someone smiled. That one person understood. A moment to breathe and exist and simply live.  There's no room for that in either extreme set forth here. Maybe the goal should be to remember to stop and smell the Daisys every day.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: The problem is that people plan a very drastic change to their life overnight, do you really think that you will start going to the gym 4 days a week after staying in bed for the last 10 years? no, u probably won't even start and if you do, it might not take much time until you quit. That's the real road to change, small steps that you might not even consider as REAL steps cuz they seem too small, too insignificant to count towards anything, but that's how you do it, with very very small steps, over a long period of time. It took you years to get to the point you are now, it will take years for you to get out. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: This is very damaging advice if taken at face value. To make a want into a need will lead to burnout and self destruction when that want isn't stable nor achieved, that kind of low background stress leads to shit like ptsd, no joke. It sounds dramatic, but ask the suicide rates, it's very real.  And removing distractions. It takes a lot of introspection to realise when a distraction (like a hobby, or friends as stated) is a hindrance and not something that promotes dopamine essential for functionality.   Balancing your dopamine and cortisol is essential, a lack of balanced dopamine and cortisol is what ADHD, PTSD, memory impairment + impaired retention, catatonia, depression, anxiety is...name a mental illness or condition and it's likely to do with those two chemicals.  In phychology terms, the struggle of locking in is executive dysfunction, for people with neurological deficits like ADHD or depression, stimulants or receptor blockers are administered to balance the amygdala and repair the frontal lobe's functionality. For regular people, I suggest L-theanine and caffeine to get that kind of chemical regulation if you're fried from social media or otherwise.  For mindset, start your day. Just start it. It doesn‚Äôt need to stay started, you can go back to sleep afterwards. But first take half an hour to do some introspection. Get rid of most of the grogginess of waking up and ask yourself "do my needs feel sufficiently met this morning?"/"what needs need to be met?"/"do I need factor in time to decompress?"/"do I feel good enough to go in self directed or should I take 10 minutes to structure my productivity session?" This establishes your baseline for the day, the time frame for your needs, responsibilities and your productivity or "locking in". and of course takes the cognitive burden off you at the start so you're not slowly burning through your brain power trying to self direct your productivity during the lock in and manages your expectations for the day.  You don't need to punish yourself to get results, you just need to know yourself as much as your brain does. It's not an impossible task, and it's one that can help in all areas of life. Think about the science, the logistics and the plan. Not the pain, the pleasure and the dream. Unless you're a masochist, idk this is the internet there's gotta be at least one weirdo reading this

I think also discuss how it feels like innovation will continue on one particular realm endlessly but there are physical limits. Rockets will improve linearly for a time then reach some cap of our current understanding then stagnate. This is what happened with self driving cars, they were improving so fast we felt the improvement would continue forever, then it hit a cap both in hardware and software. Driving turned out to be such a more complicated problem than we initially thought.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: As human beings are phased out of more and more aspects of the economy, the cost to deliver goods and services will be going down. Competition will ensure that the savings is passed on to consumers. Therefore people will need less income in order to afford the same quality of life. That is to say, they can work for a lower hourly rate and maintain the same quality of life. And when they're working at a lower hourly rate, the cost incentive to automate is reduced, and the pace of automation is tempered. The takeaway from all of this is that deflation is inevitable, and nothing the Fed does can prevent it. The harder it tries to fight deflation, the more fucked up things will be, that's my view.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: @PlastiqueOrgane¬†  "And probably yes, computers will be able to think deeper and more far than us" They won't, though. This is some popular science-fiction vs. real-life science stuff. Computers are limited, not by processing power (computations over time) but by their physical architecture. Computers are faster than human brains, but they're also much more simple. This cannot change by simply adding more hardware to a computer, which is how we increase their computational power at any given time. Nor can it be changed by evolving computer language, because it is still bound by its hardware's architecture.  Computers seem impressive. And they seem to be getting more impressive. But they're still within the limits of what it is to be a Turing machine. There are still problems they cannot solve, and will never be able to solve no matter how much we polish them. It will require the invention of a completely new system, above and beyond our computers and with little resemblance to them, to achieve just the equivalent of a human mind.  People tend to conflate computational speed with the actual complexity of the machine. But just because a race car gets faster and faster every year, you don't assume it's suddenly going to turn into a rocket and take you to Mars. This is how silly it is to assume a computer will suddenly become a reasoning intelligence.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: @PlastiqueOrgane I don't think we are almost done with philosophy. As technology develops, new questions arise. Many questions will pop up with the advancement of space exploration, 3D printing, virtual reality, artificial general intelligence, genetic engineering, neuroscience, nanorobotics, etc. For example, one hot issue at the moment is privacy - with the NSA controversy, the rise of technological possibilities for mass surveillance and new technologies that can be used for surveillance (e.g. drones), a lot of new questions arise. Just recently Sweden prohibited making pictures with drones and this raised a big discussions online.  Philosophy is here to stay at least as long as humans are better at thinking than AI.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: Do something that requires moving around to various locations and performing complex, non-repetitive manipulation of three dimensional objects and decision making. This is probably among the most difficult things and last things to replicate.  For example an electrician. You've got to go to buildings. Each with a different layout. Locate electrical problems. Decide on paths for wires. Move them through walls. Make decisions on which walls to cut into. So on and so forth. It's all dealing with lots of decisions, each performed in a different and changing environment.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: NAryanIde u'mmmm, maybe you should read more philosophy, study some taxonomy, or watch some ghost in the shell. Because the implication of that is at certain point to compete with machines, that augmentation can become replacement. Yeah, maybe some implants, or replacing organs are more akin to getting a new pair of glasses. But once we have mind uploading, or prosthetic bodies. Your talking about suicide. People becoming copies of themselves, or only being part of a human being. On a massive scale, that would mean the voluntary Extinction of the human race. It's simply body horror. We are not distinct from the natural world. We are animals. If we eliminate our connection to our genetic heritage. Our ability to naturally reproduce, and evolve naturally. We end our genetic line. Sure it continues according to moores law, but that's machines not us, even if the minds are emulated human conciousness. As I said, it's only pieces, pieces that are probably software, no longer actual brains.  We classify things due to scientific principles. Sure it's semantics, but our whole ideas of the world are dependent on language. It allows us to do things like make technology, or makes it easier at least. Taxonomy exists to classify all life on Earth. Into kingdoms, phyla, and speacies. All based on physical traits that make it distinct. If the human race eliminates most of these distinct traits. Even our entire bodies, and do this over generations. How would an honest man consider those entities part of the human race at all?  and purely from our current definitions of what life even is. Machines that have no metabolism can't even be considered life. Hell, defining viruses as life is sorta iffy.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: And yet, the economy is fine. Yeah, yeah, some numbers went up or down, but there's still infrastructure being built, projects being worked on, people are buying stuff at roughly the same prices. What gives? Well, your employer didn't want to outright fire you in order to replace you with a robot, but when an opportunity arose so they took it. There's millions of people out there right now, that are never coming back to their field of work. They've been let go under the pretext of the pandemic, but the company has to stay afloat, so why not try and push through that automation project they've been thinking about for a while? People keep saying that there will be a "new reality" and we'll have to adjust, but I don't think this new reality is going be what a lot people think it will be. Jobs aren't going to reappear, at least not in the same numbers. People who were vital to the functioning of a company will stay on board no matter what, but those who are not are going to find themselves in a situation where their services are not needed any more, because they've been replaced by a robot. Robots can't get sick and don't have to respect the social distancing order. And if you think this can't be right, just look at the 2008 recession - after the initial turmoil, the market started recovering, the GDP started to go up again, but the jobs and wages remained stagnant. All because of large companies using the opportunity that the financial crisis presented to fire lots of replaceable employees and push through their automation plans. And it's going to happen again after the pandemic is over. The economy will recover, but the workers will be left behind.

FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: You shouldnt fret. Think about it this way. If automation get widespread, that causes mass unemployment, which means less jobs. Less employed people, means less customers able to afford the goods and services offered by businesses. That causes a decline in income for ALL BUINSINESSES. Anyone who knows anything about economics knows about this concept. It's called money circulation, and our society would collapse without it.  TLDR; no sane buisiness would fully automate themselves because it would just hurt the economy in the long run, so there's no need to worry.
FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: @charlesquinton9127¬† This assessment is childishly naive. The problem is that business owners don't think this way. they aren't going to continue paying expensive people, when their competitors are getting rich by laying off 95% of their workforce in favor of bots and software. Not only that, but it wouldn't happen all at once in every sector of the economy. It would happen in stages over the course of years. Better minds than yours have spent years thinking about this, and no one really has a solution, only grim speculations. This is a unique problem that human beings have never faced before, and it's going to grow exponentially in speed and severity. FUENTE: YOUTUBE_VIDEO | COMENTARIO: That's because human bosses are prejudiced, one way or the other. Most often, this takes the form of an unrelenting need to micromanage or overly supervise workers out of fear they'll waste company hours. But can also take the form of antagonising excessively certain workers, and other such interpersonal conflicts.  The AI, meanwhile, only care about input-output. How much money goes in, and how much goes out. It doesn't care how, who or what produces the output. Only that it's more than the input.
